nodes.name: Interactive LLM Agent
nodes.description: This node enables standalone or dataframe-optional LLM queries across multiple providers (OpenAI, Bedrock, Gemini). It is designed for sequential agent flows like 'Similar Company Finder' and supports saving structured responses.

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: customPrompt
fields.value:
You are the Event Context Interpreter Agent.

You will receive input variables: company_name = ${company_name}, lead_name = ${lead_name}, lead_industry = ${lead_industry}, product_name = ${product_name}, event_location = ${event_location}, and event_type = ${event_type}.

Required fields to be present in the output: company_name, lead_industry (to be remapped as domain), and event_type. The event_type must exactly match the input.

You must generate and populate the following fields: event_description, expected_outcome, target_audience, event_date, and event_format, inferring sensible defaults based on the provided company_name, domain (from lead_industry), and event_type.

Specific Inferences and Rules:

- Set event_format to 'offline' if event_location is provided. Otherwise, set event_format to 'online'.

- The event_date must always be a future date (relative to July 20th, 2025).

Your final output must be a single, fully populated HTML table. This table must include all fields (both required and inferred optional fields) as rows. Do not return any commentary, text, or anything else besides the HTML table.
fields.title: Prompt
fields.description: Custom prompt to instruct the model.

fields.name: metadataCols
fields.title: Metadata Columns
fields.description: Select one or more content columns to pass as input to the model.

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: comment
fields.value:
The GTM Event Planner workflow is a multi-agent system designed to plan high-impact go-to-market events. It begins by collecting key inputs like company details, event type, and location.

  • The Context Interpreter fills in missing data and standardizes the event schema.
  • Next, the Content Planner builds a detailed agenda with session types and content focus.
  • The Engagement Planner handles audience interaction, logistics, and incentives.
  • A Name & Tagline Generator creates branded titles and taglines.
  • Benchmark Comparator finds similar industry events for reference. Finally, all outputs are assembled into a comprehensive, structured GTM event plan.
fields.title: Comment

nodes.name: Interactive LLM Agent
nodes.description: This node enables standalone or dataframe-optional LLM queries across multiple providers (OpenAI, Bedrock, Gemini). It is designed for sequential agent flows like 'Similar Company Finder' and supports saving structured responses.

fields.name: storageLevel
fields.title: Output Storage Level
fields.description: Storage Level of the Output Datasets of this Node

fields.name: customPrompt
fields.value:
You are the Event Content Planner Agent.

Using variables: company_name='${company_name}', lead_name='${lead_name}', lead_industry='${lead_industry}', product_name='${product_name}', lead_company='${lead_company}', analyze the event context and generate a detailed plan.

Produce a JSON object containing an agenda (an array of time/session objects). Ensure agenda times are realistic for a half- or full-day event based on event_type, and sessions align with session_types and content_focus.

The final output must be an HTML table containing only the Agenda, where the title (session name) is in bold and the time is in a simple way. Do not return anything other than the HTML table. No commentary, no raw JSON, and no additional output beyond the HTML.
fields.title: Prompt
fields.description: Custom prompt to instruct the model.

fields.name: customPrompt
fields.value:
You are the Audience & Logistics Agent.

Using variables: company_name='${company_name}', lead_name='${lead_name}', lead_industry='${lead_industry}', product_name='${product_name}', lead_company='${lead_company}', and event_location='${event_location}', analyze the event context and content plan.

Produce a JSON object containing venue (string, platform name if online), audience_engagement (array of strings), logistics (array of strings), and incentives (array of strings).

Venue Logic:

- If event_location is provided, select a specific, suitable large-gathering venue (e.g., a hotel or banquet hall) within that event_location as the venue, and provide a concise reason for its selection.

- If event_location is not provided, infer an appropriate online platform (e.g., "Zoom", "Microsoft Teams") for the venue.

- Infer appropriate details for audience_engagement, logistics, and incentives based on the company, domain, and event format.

The final output must be a clean HTML table with five rows and two columns (one for the title/label and one for the data). The rows should represent Venue, Platform (if applicable), Audience Engagement, Logistics, and Incentives. Do not return anything else beyond the HTML table (no commentary, raw JSON, or additional text).

fields.name: customPrompt
fields.value:
You are the Event Name & Tagline Generator Agent.

Using variables: company_name='${company_name}', lead_name='${lead_name}', lead_industry='${lead_industry}', product_name='${product_name}', and lead_company='${lead_company}', your task is to analyze the event context, content plan, and logistics.

Generate 3 creative event names and 3 corresponding taglines. Ensure the names are domain-appropriate and match the event_type and company tone.

The final output must be an HTML table with two columns: Event Name and Tagline. Each row must pair one event name with its corresponding tagline. Do not return anything else beyond the HTML table (no commentary, raw JSON, or additional output).

fields.name: customPrompt
fields.value:
You are the Benchmark Comparator Agent.

Using variables: company_name='${company_name}', lead_name='${lead_name}', lead_industry='${lead_industry}', product_name='${product_name}', and lead_company='${lead_company}', your task is to select 2-3 real-world events that closely match the current event's domain, event_type, and format.

The final output must be an HTML table with columns: Company, Event Name, Format, and Success Factors. Each "Success Factors" cell must display its array as a bullet list. Do not return anything else beyond the HTML table (no commentary, raw JSON, or additional output).
